lg.l: ASF.9.1: The ornamental capital is in red and green ink with red and green flourishes running from the top to the bottom of the page in the left margin. y lay & lokede forÃ¾ / lowe vp-on Ã¾e greene.
I fel in a slumbrynge / & sone to me cam keende.F.9.2: F's reading is unique. Bx reads "And slepynge I seiÈ al Ã¾is and siÃ¾en cam kynde."
& nempnyd me by my name / & bad me nemyn hede.
Of Ã¾e worchynge of Ã¾is world / wit for to take.
& on heyÈ Mounteyn / Ã¾at Mydlerd hette.F.9.5: F omits Bx's "as me Ã¾o Ã¾ouÈte."
I was Ã¾idir fet forÃ¾ / ensamples to knowe
Ãoru euery creatures keende / my creatur to loveye.
I sey Ã¾e sunne & Ã¾e see / & Ã¾e sond after.
& bryddis & beestis / by here makes wentyn.

& wyÈlde wluesF.9.10: F uniquely reads wlues. Other B manuscripts have wormes. wlues, "wolves." Though appearing only this one time in F, the use of <w> alone for <wu> appears once in R as well (wlueliche R15.131, KD15.116) and may perhaps be attributed to alpha. in wodis / & wondirful foulis.
With flekkede fedres / & fele faire coloures.
BoÃ¾e man & his make / ful manye seyÈ y Ã¾ere.F.9.12: F uniquely reads "ful manye seyÈ y Ã¾ere." R has "I miÈte se bothe," and beta manuscripts have "I myÈte boÃ¾e biholde."
BoÃ¾e pouerte & plente / & eek pees & werre.
Blisse & also bale / y seyÈ Ã¾ere boÃ¾e at oonysatoonys.
& men tooke Meede / & Mercy for-soke

Â¶ Thanne Resoun shewede me / alle manere beestis.F.9.16: F's line is substantially revised. Other B manuscripts have "Reson I seiÈ sooÃ¾ly sewen alle beestes." Alpha is likely to have been responsible for shewede since R has schewen.
In etynge & drynkynge / in gendrynge of keende.

& after cours of concepcioun / non took keep of oÃ¾ir.F.9.18: F omits the following three lines from Bx:
As whan Ã¾ei hadde ryde in Rotey tyme anoon riÈt Ã¾er-after
Males drowen hem to males amorwenynges by hemselue
And in euenynges also Èede (or beta's Ã¾e?) males fro femelles.
Ãar was non kow Ã¾oru kyÈnde / Ã¾at conceyvid hadde.
Ãat wolde belwe after bole / ne boor after sowe.
Ne grete hors ne hakeneys / after oÃ¾ire beestis.
Ne Ã¾ey medlid not with here makis / save man oone.
Â¶ I be-held bryddis also / in busshis Ã¾ey made nestis.
Was neuere Èit wyÈe / hadde wit / to wirche Ã¾e leeste.

div1.l: I hadde wondir of whom / & where Ã¾e pyÈe lernede.F.9.25: The scribe has written in red with red flourishes the numeral "IX" in the top right margin to indicate the passus number.
Stykkis to legge / in lengÃ¾e & in breede.F.9.26: F's reading is unique. Other B manuscripts have "To legge Ã¾e stikkes in which she leyeÃ¾ and bredeÃ¾."
Ãere is no wryghte as y wene / can wirche to hire paye.F.9.27: F's b-verse is unique. Bx reads "sholde werche hir nest to paye."
Ne Masoun to make a Moolde Ã¾erto / myche merveyleF.9.28: F uniquely reads merveyle. Bx has wonder. it were.

lg.l: Â¶ Èyt merveylid y moore / ofF.9.29: FG alone read of. Other B manuscripts have how. manye oÃ¾ire bryddis.
Ãey heledyn & heddyn / here heggysF.9.30: An inverse spelling for eggys. ful derne.

With MoosF.9.31: Moos, "moss." / in Ã¾e MaryÈs / Ã¾at men ne sholde hem fyÈnde.F.9.31: F is revised significantly. Bx reads as follows:
In Mareys and moores for men sholde hem noÈt fynde
And hidden hir egges whan Ã¾ei Ã¾erfro wente.
& feer of oÃ¾ire fowlys / & for wyÈlde beestys.
Summe tredyn here makys / & on trees breden.
Â¶ & brynge forÃ¾ here bryddis / al a-bove Ã¾e grounde.
& summe blowe bele in bele / & with here breeÃ¾ conseyve.F.9.35: Other B witnesses read: "And some briddes at Ã¾e bile Ã¾oruÈ breÃ¾yng conceyued."
& summe kawkede y tok keep / as pekokys wirche.
Â¶ Mychil merveylede me Ã¾an / what mayster Ã¾ey hadde.
& who tawhte hem on trees / to tyÈmbre so hyÈe.
Fram alle beestys / here bryddis to save.F.9.39: F's line is unique. Other B manuscripts have "Ther neiÃ¾er burn ne beest may hir briddes rechen."
Â¶ & after y lookede on Ã¾e see / & on Ã¾e sterris bryghte.
& manye selkouÃ¾is y seyÈ / y may not seyÈ nowÃ¾e.
Â¶ I seyÈ flowres in Ã¾e frythÈ / with ful fayre colourys.F.9.42: The <c> is written more like <t> with an ascender.
Ãat a-mongis Ã¾e grene gras / grewe ful soote.
Summe soote & summe sowr / gret selkouÃ¾ me Ã¾ouhte
But of here keende coloures / to carpe were to longe.
Â¶ But Ã¾at most merveyled me / & made my mood to change.
Ãat Resoun took reward / & rewlede alle beestis.
Save man / & his make / manye tymesF.9.48: Alpha is responsible for unmetrical tymes. Beta manuscripts have tyme. & ofte.
No resoun rewlyÃ¾ hem / & y rebewkyd hym Ã¾anne.
& Ã¾us sadly to hym / my-seluen y seyÈde.
Â¶ I have wondir of Ã¾e . quod y ï ¡ Ã¾at Resoun art holde.

Ãou makst man & his make / no myschef hem folwe.F.9.52: F has miscomprehended the sense here. Bx reads "Why Ã¾ow ne sewest man and his make Ã¾at no mysfeet hem folwe." Alpha was quite possibly corrupt since R has schewest for sewest.
Â¶ Ãan Resoun a-ratid me / & seyde recche Ã¾e neuere.
Why y suffre . or not suffre / Ã¾ou hast not to doone.

A-mende it / Ã¾ou myght not / but tyÈme y a-byÈde.F.9.55: This line represents a succession of small errors followed by scribal smoothing in an attempt to make sense of botched copy. Bx reads as follows: "Amende Ã¾ow it if Ã¾ow myÈt for my tyme is to abide."
Suffrance is a souereyn vertu / & vengable is vengaunceF.9.56: The b-verse in other B manuscripts reads "and a swift vengeaunce."
Suffrance god suffrede / to goomes as y leve.F.9.57: F's reading is unique. Bx reads "Who suffreÃ¾ moore Ã¾an god quod he no gome as I leeue."

He myghte a-mende hem in a while / alle Ã¾at mys-fonde.F.9.58: MED, s. v. misfÅn, "to make a mistake," occurs only here and in an early thirteenth-century devotional text, though the word is common in Old English. Bx reads "al Ã¾at mysstandeÃ¾."
& Èit he suffreÃ¾ / for sum mannys goode / & so is oure bettre.

Holy writ . quod Ã¾at weyÈ / wyssheÃ¾F.9.60: The scribe wrote <ssh> where we might expect <ss> for this word. WyssheÃ¾ here is a form of wisseÃ¾, "teaches, counsels, instructs." men to suffre. These thirteen lines appear only in alpha.

lg.l: Â¶ Now wille Èe leere a tale / was told me in towne.
How Frensshe men in France / a-faytyn here childryn.

eele vertue est suffraunce ï ¡ mal dire est pety vengance.

ien dire & bien suffre ï ¡ fait lui suffrant a bien venir.

lg.l: / [Â¶] For-Ã¾y ï ¡ y rede Ã¾e Resoun / Ã¾ou rewle better Ã¾y tunge.
& er Ã¾ou my lyf lakke / looke Ã¾yn be to preyse.
For Ã¾ere is no creature vndir criÈst / can formen hym-selue.
& yf a man myghte / make lakles hym-selue.
Ech man wolde ben lakles / leve Ã¾ou non oÃ¾ir.
Ne shalt fyÈnde but fewe / fayn wolde heere.
Of here fowle defawtys / be-fore here face reersed.

t vidit deus cuntacun[c]ta que fecerat ï ¡ & erant ualde bona.

lg.l: God bad ech creature / in his kyÈnde encrese.
& al was to merthe with man / Ã¾at most woo Ã¾olyeÃ¾
In foondynge of his fleshÈ / & of Ã¾e feend boÃ¾e.
For man was maad of mater / he may not fro it sterte.
Ãat sum-tyme hym but suffre / to folwe his keÈnde.
Catoun a-cordiÃ¾ Ã¾erto / nemo sine crimine viuit.
/ [Â¶] Ão cawhte y colour a-non / & cumsede to ben a-shamed.
& y awakede Ã¾ere-with / & woo was y thanne.
Ãat y ne myghte in Metelys / more matere y-knowe.
Ãanne chidde y my-selue / & seyde Ã¾ese woordis.F.9.88: F's reading is unique. Bx reads "And Ã¾anne seide I to myself and chidde Ã¾at tyme."
Now what Dowel ys quod y ï ¡ by dere god y knowe.
& as y keste vp myn eyÈes / oon lokede on me & askede.

What Ã¾yng Ã¾at Dowel ys / y-wis sire y not y seyde.F.9.91: F revises two problematic lines from Bx into one. Bx reads as follows:
Of me what Ã¾yng it were ywis sire I seide
To se muche and suffre moore certes quod I is dowel.
Â¶ Ãan seyde he haddist Ã¾ou suffred / Ã¾o Ã¾ou on slepe were.
Ãou sholdist have knowe it of Clergye / & conseyvid it be resoun.
For Resoun wolde have reersyd Ã¾e / ryght as Clergye seydeF.9.94: F omits the following line from Bx: "Ac for Ã¾yn entremetynge here artow forsake."

hilosophus esses ï ¡ si tacuisses.

lg.l: Adam whilis he was heere / he hadde paradyÈs at his wille.
& whan he mamelede on his mete / he menede to knowe.

& ryÈht so ferde Resoun / be Ã¾yn rude speche.
Ãou lakkedist lordly Ã¾yng / Ã¾at longyd Ã¾e not to done.
He hadde after no lykynge / for to leere Ã¾e moore.
/ [Â¶] & now wil priÈde & presumsyoun / paraunter Ã¾e a-peele.

Ãat ClergyÈe inF.9.103: Alpha is responsible for in, which is omitted in Beta manuscripts. Ã¾yn cumpanye / nowht coueytyÃ¾F.9.103: F uniquely reads "nowht coueytyÃ¾." Other B manuscripts have "ne kepeÃ¾ noÈt." eft to sytte.F.9.103: Alpha reads "eft to sytte." Beta manuscripts have "to suwe."

For leete a drunke daffe / in a deep dyÈk falle.
& lete hym lygge longe Ã¾ere / tyl hym lyste to ryÈse.
& Ã¾ey Resoun rebewke hym / Èit rekkeÃ¾ he neuere. Beta omits these verses through eye-skip on Bx's "hym Ã¾anne."
Of Clergye ne of his conseil / he a-cownteÃ¾ not a resshe.
For to betyn hym Ã¾anne / it were but pure synne.
But whan neede nemeÃ¾ hym vp / for dowhte leest he sterve.F.9.111: F omits Bx's "And shame shrapeÃ¾ hise cloÃ¾es and hise shynes wassheÃ¾."
Ãanne whot Ã¾at drunke daffe / wherfore he is to blame.

Ãere smyt no man so smerte / ne skumfyÈteÃ¾F.9.114: F uniquely reads skumfyÈteÃ¾. Other B manuscripts have smelleÃ¾. non so sore
As shame dooÃ¾ Ã¾ere he sheweth hym / no man loveÃ¾ his felachipe.F.9.115: Alpha is responsible for the b-verse. Beta manuscripts have the also defective reading "for euery man hym shonyeÃ¾."
/ [Â¶] Why wyÈsse Èee me Ã¾us . quod y ï ¡ for y rebewked so Resoun.
Sertys quod he Ã¾at ys sooÃ¾ / & shoop hym for to walke.
& gan faren on hys weyÈ / & y folwede after.F.9.118: F has recomposed the line. Bx reads "And I aroos vp riÈt wiÃ¾ Ã¾at and folwed hym after."

& y have folwid Ã¾e in feyÃ¾ / fyve & fowrty wynter.

& on Ã¾yn wyÈlde wantounnesse / Ã¾o Ã¾ow in Èowthe were.

lg.l: A-mende Ã¾e while Ã¾ou myght / Ã¾ou hast be warned ofte.

F.9.132: Alpha omits the following two lines:
And Dauid in Ã¾e Sauter seiÃ¾ of swiche Ã¾at loueÃ¾ Iesus
Virga tua & baculus tuus ipsa me consolata sunt.

lg.l: / [Â¶] Al-Ã¾eyhÈ Ã¾ou strike me with goddis staf / with-outyn stykkes soreF.9.133: The b-verse makes little sense. Bx reads "wiÃ¾ stikke or wiÃ¾ yerde."

Why medlyst Ã¾e with makyngF.9.135: Alpha and M have the possibly correct singular form. Beta manuscripts have the plural makynges. Ã¾an / Ã¾ou myght bettre go praye.
& bydde for hem Ã¾at Èeve Ã¾e breed / for Ã¾ere be bookis y-nouwe.
To tellyn what ys . dobet / & Dowel . bothe.F.9.137: F's reading is unique. Bx reads "To telle men what dowel is dobet and dobest boÃ¾e."
& prechoures to preve what it is / of many a peyre freris.
Ãan wiste y wel he seyde sooÃ¾ / & Ã¾ouhte me to excuse.
&F.9.140: Alpha is responsible for &. Beta manuscripts omit it. seyde Catoun confortyd his sone / ful konyngly y wene.F.9.140: F's b-verse is unique. Bx reads "Ã¾at clerk Ã¾ouÈ he were."

Sum-tyme to solace hym-selue / & sum-tymesadly to stodie.F.9.141: F's reading for this line is unique. Bx reads "To solacen hym som-tyme as I do whan I make." The excision of sadly to before stodie by lining through is not entirely characteristic of this scribe, and it is possible that he did not intend to omit to.

Er salomon his sapience / or sampson his strengthe.

Er Felyce for hire fayrnesse / yt fel hire al to sklaundre.
& Rosemound ryght soo / rewfully she be-sette.

& namely Clergye for cristis love / for he knoweth Ã¾e roote.F.9.198: Bx reads "Ã¾at of Clergie is roote."

For god wroot to Moyses / Ã¾at he sholde wisse Ã¾e peple. The elaborate hypotactic structure of Bx and the loss of a line in alpha appear to have defeated the revising scribe. He retains key words, but fails adequately to capture the sense. Bx reads for this passage:
For Moyses witnesseÃ¾ Ã¾at god wroot for to wisse Ã¾e peple
In Ã¾e olde lawe as Ã¾e lettre telleÃ¾ Ã¾at was Ã¾e lawe of Iewes
That what womman were in auoutrye taken wher she riche or poore
WiÃ¾ stones men sholde hir strike and stone hire to deÃ¾e
A womman as we fynden was gilty of Ã¾at dede
Ac crist of his curteisie Ã¾oruÈ clergie hir saued
For Ã¾oruÈ caractes Ã¾at crist wroot Ã¾e Iewes knewe hemselue
Giltier as afore god and gretter in synne.
Affter Ã¾e lettre tellyÃ¾ / Ã¾e lawe so was to Ã¾e Iewis.
What womman was take in a-vowtery / where she ryche or pore.

F.9.315: Scribal ".a." appears in the left margin, indicating that the scribe intended that this line, originally written after F9.317, should precede it instead. The actual order in the manuscript is the order of Bx, and presumably this reflects's F's immediate exemplar, but we have followed the scribe's instruction as to his own intention. The change is attributable not to F-Redactor but to the immediate scribe. & sytte boordles beggerely / be my-selue on grownde.
F.9.316: The scribe has written ".b." in the left margin by this line. See the textual note to the preceding line for discussion. I have meete ryght a-nowh / but not so myche worchepe.

For other agreements among these manuscripts, see F9.176, 388. / with Ã¾e souereyn of Ã¾e place.

hi.hi: Et alibi . Si ambulauero in medio vmbre mortis non timebo mala quoniam tu mecum es domine.

l.note: F.9.412: F uniquely reads "non timebo mala quoniam tu mecum es domine." Other B manuscripts conclude the line with mortis.
